feat.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: Increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feat. However, if you're at least level 19, that maximum increases to 22.

spell.name: Arcane Eruption
entries: Churning magical energy explodes in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you choose within range. When you cast the spell, you select the type of damage dealt by the explosion: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, Poison, Psychic, or Thunder. Each creature in the sphere must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 6d6} damage of the chosen type. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage.

Choose one of those d6s. The number rolled on that die determines a condition that's applied to each creature that failed the save, as shown below. A creature has the condition until the end of your next turn.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 5 or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledamage 6d6|4-9|1d6} for each slot level above 4.

spell.name: Counterspell

time.condition: which you take when you see a creature within 60 feet of yourself casting a spell with Verbal, Somatic, or Material components

entries: You attempt to interrupt a creature in the process of casting a spell. The creature must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the spell dissipates with no effect, and the action, Bonus Action, or Reaction used to cast it is wasted. If that spell was cast with a spell slot, the slot isn't expended.

spell.name: Jump
entries: You touch a willing creature. Once on each of its turns until the spell ends, that creature can jump up to 30 feet by spending only 10 feet of movement.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of level 2 or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1.

spell.name: Sorcerous Burst
entries: You cast sorcerous energy at one creature or object within range. Make a ranged attack roll against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d8} damage. If you roll an 8 on a {@dice d8} for this spell, you can roll another {@dice d8}, and add it to the damage. Whenever you cast this spell, the maximum number of these {@dice d8|d8s} you can add to the spell's damage equals your spellcasting ability modifier.
You choose the damage type each time you cast this spell: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, Poison, Psychic, or Thunder.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Cantrip Upgrade
entries: This spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d8} when you reach level 5 ({@dice 2d8}), 11 ({@dice 3d8}), and 17 ({@dice 4d8}).

baseitem.name: Lance
entries: {@note The lance does not have the Two-Handed property when mounted.}

item.name: Net
entries: When you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} action on your turn, you can replace one of your attacks with a throw of the net at a creature within 15 feet of yourself. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw against a DC equal to 8 + your Proficiency Bonus + your Dexterity modifier. The target succeeds automatically if it's Huge or larger.

On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Restrained} condition until it escapes the net. To escape, the target must use its action to make a {@dc 10} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check, escaping on a success. A creature within 5 feet of the target can use its action to attempt the same thing. Destroying the net (AC 10; 5 HP; immunity to Bludgeoning, Poison, and Psychic damage) also frees the target, ending the effect.

item.name: Priest's Pack
entries: A Priest's Pack contains the following items:

entries.name: Heavy
entries: A Heavy weapon is unwieldy compared to other weapons. You have Disadvantage on your attack rolls with a Heavy weapon if it's a melee weapon and your Strength score isn't at least 13 and if it's a ranged weapon and your Dexterity score isn't at least 13.

entries.name: Light
entries: When you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} action on your turn and attack with a Light weapon, you can make one extra attack as a Bonus Action later on the same turn. That extra attack must be made with a different Light weapon, and you don't add your ability modifier to the extra attack's damage, unless that modifier is negative.

For example, if you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} action on your turn and have a Shortsword in one hand and a Dagger in the other—each of which has the Light property—you can make one attack with each weapon, using your action and a Bonus Action, but you don't add your Strength or Dexterity modifier to the damage roll of the Bonus Action, unless that modifier is negative.

entries.name: Thrown
entries: If a weapon has the Thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack, and you can draw that weapon as part of the attack.

If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a Handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a Dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the Dagger has the Finesse property.

itemMastery.name: Cleave
entries: If you hit a creature with a melee attack using this weapon, you can make an attack roll with the weapon against a second creature within 5 feet of the first that is also within your reach. On a hit, the second creature takes the weapon's damage, but don't add your ability modifier to that damage, unless that modifier is negative. You can make this extra attack only once per turn.

itemMastery.name: Graze
entries: If your attack roll with this weapon misses a creature, you can deal damage to that creature equal to the ability modifier you used to make the attack roll. This damage is the same type dealt by the weapon, and the damage can't be increased in any way, other than increasing the ability modifier.

itemMastery.name: Nick
entries: When you make the extra attack of the Light property, you can make it as part of the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} action, instead of as a Bonus Action. You can still make this extra attack only once per turn.

itemMastery.name: Push
entries: If you hit a creature with this weapon, you can push the creature up to 10 feet straight away from yourself if it is Large or smaller.

itemMastery.name: Sap
entries: If you hit a creature with this weapon, that creature has Disadvantage on its next attack roll before the start of your next turn.

itemMastery.name: Slow
entries: If you hit a creature with this weapon and deal damage to the creature, you can reduce its Speed by 10 feet until the start of your next turn. If you hit the creature more than once with this property, the Speed reduction doesn't exceed 10 feet.

itemMastery.name: Topple
entries: If you hit a creature with this weapon, you can force the creature to make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to 8 + your Proficiency Bonus + the ability modifier used to make the attack roll. On a failed save, the creature has the {@condition Prone} condition.

itemMastery.name: Vex
entries: If you hit a creature with this weapon and deal damage to the creature, you have Advantage on your next attack roll against that creature before the end of your next turn.

variantrule.name: Armor Training
entries: Armor training is the new name for armor proficiency. Any existing rule that involves armor proficiency now applies to armor training.

If you wear Light, Medium, or Heavy Armor and lack armor training with that type of armor, you have Disadvantage on any {@variantrule D20 Tests|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|d20 Test} you make that involves Strength or Dexterity, and you can't cast spells.
If you equip a Shield and lack armor training with it, you don't gain the Armor Class bonus of the Shield.

variantrule.name: Bonus Feats at Level 20
entries: A DM can use bonus feats as a form of advancement after characters reach level 20 to provide greater power to characters who have no more levels to gain. With this approach, each character gains one feat of their choice for every 30,000 XP the character earns above 355,000 XP. Epic Boon feats are especially appropriate for these bonus feats, but a player can choose any feat for which their level 20 character qualifies.

variantrule.name: Climb Speed
entries: A Climb Speed can be used to traverse a vertical surface without expending the extra movement normally associated with climbing.
Some creatures have the Spider Climb trait, which allows their Climb Speed to work even on the underside of horizontal surfaces.

variantrule.name: Creature Type
entries: Every creature in D&D, including every player character, has a special tag in the rules that identifies the type of creature it is. Most player characters are of the Humanoid type.
Here's a list of the game's creature types in alphabetical order:

These types don't have rules themselves, but some rules in the game affect creatures of certain types in different ways. For example, the description of the {@spell Charm Person} spell specifies that its target must be a Humanoid.

variantrule.name: D20 Tests
entries: The term d20 Test encompasses the three main {@dice d20} rolls of the game: ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws. If something in the game affects d20 Tests, it affects all three of these rolls.
The DM determines whether a d20 Test is warranted in any given circumstance.

variantrule.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: If a space is Difficult Terrain, every foot of movement in that space costs 1 extra foot. For example, moving 5 feet through Difficult Terrain costs 10 feet of movement. Difficult Terrain isn't cumulative; either a space is Difficult Terrain or it isn't.
A space is Difficult Terrain for a creature if the space contains any of the following:

items: Creature that isn't Tiny or your ally
Furniture that is one size smaller than you or larger
Liquid that's between shin- and waist-deep (any deeper and you need to swim)
Narrow opening that is sized for a creature one size smaller
Pit or another gap of 2–5 feet

entries: The DM may determine that other things make a space count as Difficult Terrain, based on the examples here.

variantrule.name: Expertise
entries: Expertise is a special feature that enhances your use of a particular skill proficiency. If you gain Expertise, you gain it in one skill in which you have proficiency. You can never have Expertise in the same skill proficiency more than once.
When you make an ability check with a skill proficiency in which you have Expertise, your Proficiency Bonus is doubled for that check.

variantrule.name: Fly Speed
entries: A Fly Speed can be used to travel through the air. While you have a Fly Speed, you can stay aloft until you land, fall, or die.
While flying, you fall if you lack the Hover trait and have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} or {@condition Prone} condition or your Fly Speed is reduced to 0.

variantrule.name: Heroic Advantage
entries: When you have Heroic Advantage (also called Inspiration), you can expend it to give yourself Advantage on a {@variantrule D20 Tests|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|d20 Test}. You decide to do so immediately after rolling the {@dice d20}.

entries.name: Gaining Heroic Advantage
entries: The DM can award Heroic Advantage to a player character who's done something that is particularly heroic or in character.
Some game features, such as the Human, also award Heroic Advantage.

entries.name: Only One at a Time
entries: You can never have more than one instance of Heroic Advantage. If something gives it to you and you already have it, you can give it to a player character in your group who lacks it.

variantrule.name: Knocking Out a Creature
entries: Sometimes an attacker wants to knock out a foe rather than deal a killing blow. When an attacker would reduce a creature to 0 Hit Points with a Melee Attack, the attacker can instead reduce the creature to 1 Hit Point. The creature then has the {@condition Unconscious|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition and starts a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}.

The creature remains {@condition Unconscious|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} until it regains any Hit Points or until someone uses an action to administer first aid to it, which requires a successful {@dc 10} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check.

variantrule.name: Long Rest
entries: A Long Rest is a period of extended downtime—at least 8 hours long—available to any creature. During a Long Rest, you sleep for at least 6 hours and perform no more than 2 hours of light activity, such as reading, talking, eating, or standing watch.
During the sleep, you have the {@condition Unconscious|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition.

entries.name: Benefits of the Rest
entries: To start a Long Rest, you must have at least 1 Hit Point. When you finish the rest, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Regain All HP
entries: You regain all lost Hit Points.

items.name: Regain All HD
entries: You regain all spent Hit Dice.

items.name: HP Max Restored
entries: If your Hit Point Maximum was reduced, it returns to normal.

items.name: Ability Scores Restored
entries: If any of your Ability Scores were reduced, they return to normal.

items.name: Exhaustion Reduced
entries: If you have the {@condition Exhaustion} condition, your level of exhaustion decreases by 1.

items.name: Special Feature
entries: Some features are recharged by a Long Rest. If you have such a feature, it recharges in the way specified in its description.
After you finish a Long Rest, you must wait at least 16 hours before starting another one.

entries.name: Interrupting the Rest
entries: A Long Rest is stopped by the following interruptions:

items: Casting a spell other than a cantrip
1 hour of walking or other physical exertion

entries: If the rest was at least 1 hour long before the interruption, you gain the benefits of a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}.
You can resume a Long Rest immediately after an interruption. If you do so, the rest requires 1 additional hour to finish per interruption.

variantrule.name: Move
entries: When you Move, you can go a distance equal to your Speed or less. For example, if you have a Speed of 30 feet, you can go up to 30 feet when you Move. {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} can slow you down.

entries.name: Breaking Up Your Move
entries: You can break up your Move, using some of its movement before and after any action you take on the same turn. For example, if you have a Speed of 30 feet, you could go 10 feet, take an action, and then go 20 feet.

entries.name: Moving Around Other Creatures
entries: During your Move, you can pass through the space of an ally, a creature that has the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition, a Tiny creature, or a creature who is two sizes larger or smaller than you.
Another creature's space is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} for you, unless that creature is Tiny or your ally.
You can't willingly end your Move in a space occupied by another creature.

entries.name: Changes to Your Speeds
entries: If an effect increases or decreases your Speed for a time, any special speed you have increases or decreases by an equal amount for the same duration. For example, if your Speed is reduced to 0 and you have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, your {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} is also reduced to 0. Similarly, if your Speed is halved and you have a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, your {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} is also halved.

variantrule.name: Ritual Casting
entries: If you have a spell prepared that has the Ritual tag, you can cast that spell as a Ritual. A special feature is no longer required for Ritual casting. All the other rules on Rituals in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} still apply.

variantrule.name: Short Rest
entries: To start a Short Rest, you must have at least 1 Hit Point. When you finish the rest, you gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Benefits of the Rest
entries: To start a Short Rest, you must have at least 1 Hit Point. When you finish the rest, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Spend Hit Dice
entries: You can spend one or more of your Hit Dice to regain Hit Points. For each Hit Die you spend in this way, roll the die, and add your Constitution modifier to it. You regain Hit Points equal to the total (minimum of 1 Hit Point). You can decide to spend an additional Hit Die after each roll.

items.name: Special Feature
entries: Some features are recharged by a Short Rest. If you have such a feature, it recharges in the way specified in its description.

entries.name: Interrupting the Rest
entries: A Short Rest is stopped by the following interruptions:

items: Casting a spell other than a cantrip

entries: An interrupted Short Rest confers no benefits, and it must be started over to confer any.

variantrule.name: Swim Speed
entries: A Swim Speed can be used to travel through a liquid without expending the extra movement normally associated with swimming.

variantrule.name: Telepathy
entries: Telepathy is a magical ability that allows a creature to communicate mentally with another creature within a specified range. The contacted creature doesn't need to share a language with the telepath to understand this communication, but the contacted creature must be able to understand at least one language or be telepathic itself to understand.

A telepath doesn't need to see a contacted creature, and the telepath can start or end the telepathic contact at any time (no action required). Telepathic contact is broken as soon as the contacted creature is no longer within the telepathy's range, if the telepath contacts a different creature within range, or if the telepath has the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition.

A creature without telepathy can receive telepathic messages but can't initiate a telepathic conversation. Once a telepathic conversation starts, the nontelepath can communicate mentally to the telepath until the telepathic connection ends.

variantrule.name: Teleportation
entries: Teleportation is a special kind of magical transportation. If you teleport, you disappear and reappear elsewhere instantly, without moving through the intervening space. This transportation doesn't expend movement, unless a rule tells you otherwise, and teleportation never provokes Opportunity Attacks.

When you teleport, all the equipment you're wearing and carrying teleports with you. If you're touching another creature when you teleport, that creature doesn't teleport with you unless the teleportation effect says otherwise.
If the destination space of your teleportation is occupied by another creature or blocked by a solid obstacle, you instead appear in the nearest unoccupied space of your choice.
The description of a teleportation effect tells you if you must see the teleportation's destination.

variantrule.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: If you have proficiency with a tool, you can add your Proficiency Bonus to any ability check you make that uses that tool.

If you have proficiency in the skill that's also used with that check, you have Advantage on the check too. This means you can benefit from both a skill and a tool proficiency on the same ability check.

variantrule.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: An Unarmed Strike is a Melee attack that involves you using your body to damage, grapple, or shove a target within 5 feet of you.
Whenever you use your Unarmed Strike, choose one of the following options for its effect:

items.name: Damage
entries: You make an attack roll against the target. Your bonus to hit equals your Strength modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. On a hit, the target takes Bludgeoning damage equal to 1 + your Strength modifier.

items.name: Grapple
entries: The target must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (it chooses which), or it has the {@condition Grappled|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition. The DC for the saving throw and any escape attempts equals 8 + your Strength modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. This grapple is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you and if you have a hand free to grab it.

items.name: Shove
entries: The target must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (it chooses which), or you either push the target 5 feet away or cause it to have the {@condition Prone} condition. The DC for the saving throw equals 8 + your Strength modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. This shove is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you.

condition.name: Dazed
entries: While Dazed, you experience the following effect:

items.name: Limited Activity
entries: You can {@variantrule Move|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} or take one action on your turn, not both. You also can't take a Bonus Action or a Reaction.

condition.name: Grappled
entries: While Grappled, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Speed 0
entries: Your Speed is 0 and can't change.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: You have Disadvantage on attack rolls against any target other than the grappler.

items.name: Movable
entries: The grappler can drag or carry you when it {@variantrule Move|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Moves}, but every foot of movement costs it 1 extra foot, unless you are Tiny or two or more sizes smaller than the grappler.

items.name: Escape
entries: While Grappled, you can use your action to make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check against the grapple's escape DC, ending the condition on yourself on a success. The condition also ends if the grappler has the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition or if the distance between you and the grappler exceeds the grapple's range.

condition.name: Incapacitated
entries: While Incapacitated, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Inactive
entries: You can't take any action, Bonus Action, or Reaction.

items.name: No Concentration
entries: Your {@status Concentration} is broken.

items.name: Speechless
entries: You can't speak.

items.name: Surprised
entries: If you're Incapacitated when you roll Initiative, you have Disadvantage on the roll.

condition.name: Invisible
entries: While Invisible, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Concealed
entries: You aren't affected by any effect that requires its target to be seen.

items.name: Surprise
entries: If you're Invisible when you roll Initiative, you have Advantage on the roll.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: Attack rolls against you have Disadvantage, and your attack rolls have Advantage. If a creature can somehow see you, as with magic or {@sense Blindsight|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, you don't gain this benefit against that creature.

condition.name: Unconscious
entries: While Unconscious, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Inert
entries: You have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} and {@condition Prone} conditions, and you drop whatever you're holding. When this condition ends, you remain {@condition Prone}.

items.name: Speed 0
entries: Your Speed is 0 and can't change.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: Attack rolls against you have Advantage.

items.name: Fail Str. and Dex. Saves.
entries: You automatically fail Strength and Dexterity saving throws.

items.name: Critical Hits
entries: Any attack roll that hits you is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of you.

items.name: Unaware
entries: You're unaware of your surroundings.

action.name: Attack
entries: When you take the Attack action, you can make one attack with a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}.

entries.name: Equipping and Unequipping Weapons
entries: You can either equip or unequip one weapon when you make an attack as part of this action. You do so either before or after the attack. If you equip a weapon before an attack, you don't need to use it for that attack.
Equipping a weapon includes drawing it from a sheath, picking it up, or retrieving it from a container. Unequipping a weapon includes sheathing, stowing, or dropping it.

entries.name: Moving Between Attacks
entries: If you {@variantrule Move|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} on your turn, you can use some or all of that movement to move between the attacks of this action if you have a feature, such as Extra Attack, that gives you more than one attack as part of the Attack action.

action.name: Help
entries: When you take the Help action, you do one of the following:

items.name: Assist Ability Check
entries: Choose one of your skill or {@variantrule tool proficiency|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|tool proficiencies} and one ally who can perceive you. You give Advantage to the next ability check that ally makes with the chosen skill or tool. This benefit expires if the ally doesn't use it before the start of your next turn. To give this assistance, you must be near enough to the ally to assist verbally or physically when the ally makes the check. The DM has final say on whether your assistance is possible.

items.name: Assist Attack Roll
entries: You momentarily distract an enemy within 5 feet of you, giving Advantage to the next attack roll by one of your allies against that enemy. This benefit expires at the start of your next turn.

action.name: Hide
entries: With the Hide action, you try to conceal yourself. To do so stealthily, you must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check while you're Heavily Obscured or behind Three-Quarters Cover or Total Cover, and you must be out of any visible enemy's line of sight; if you can see a creature, you can discern whether it can see you.

On a successful check, you have the {@condition Invisible|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition. Make note of your check's total, which becomes the DC for a creature to find you with a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

The condition ends on you immediately after any of the following occurrences: you make a sound louder than a whisper, an enemy finds you, you make an attack roll, or you cast a spell with a verbal component.

action.name: Influence
entries: With the Influence action, you can try to influence another creature to do one thing that you request or demand.

The DM determines when this action is available, and it can be used only on creatures controlled by the DM. It isn't mind control; it can't force a creature to do something that is counter to the creature's alignment or that is otherwise repugnant to the creature.
This action has three main parts: Attitude, interaction, and a Charisma check.

entries.name: Attitude
entries: A creature's Attitude determines how a character can influence that creature. Each DMcontrolled creature has one of the following Attitudes toward player characters:

items.name: Indifferent
entries: This is the default Attitude for DMcontrolled creatures. An Indifferent creature might help or hinder the party, depending on what the creature sees as most beneficial. A creature's indifference doesn't necessarily make it standoffish or disinterested. Indifferent creatures might be polite and genial, surly and irritable, or anything in between. A successful Charisma check is usually necessary when the adventurers try to influence an Indifferent creature to do something.

items.name: Friendly
entries: A Friendly creature wants to help the adventurers and wishes for them to succeed. For tasks or actions that require no particular risk, effort, or cost, Friendly creatures often help happily, with the Charisma check succeeding automatically. If an element of personal risk is involved, a successful Charisma check is usually required to convince a Friendly creature to take that risk.

items.name: Hostile
entries: A Hostile creature opposes the adventurers and their goals but doesn't necessarily attack them on sight. The adventurers need to succeed on one or more Charisma checks to convince a Hostile creature to do anything on the party's behalf; however, the DM might determine that the Hostile creature is so ill-disposed toward the characters that no Charisma check can sway it. In which case, the first check fails automatically and no further Influence attempts can be made on the creature unless its Attitude shifts.

entries.name: Interaction
entries: When you take the Influence action, either roleplay how your character interacts with the creature or describe your character's behavior, focusing on your character's request or demand. If the interaction is especially suited to the creature's desires and outlook, the DM might temporarily shift a Hostile creature to Indifferent or an Indifferent creature to Friendly.
Similarly, if the interaction is particularly irksome to the creature, the DM might temporarily shift a Friendly creature to Indifferent or an Indifferent creature to Hostile.

entries.name: Charisma Check
entries: To determine whether your request or demand is successful, make a Charisma check. You have Advantage on the check if the creature is Friendly, and you have Disadvantage if the creature is Hostile.

entries.name: Choosing a Skill
entries: The Influence Skills table suggests which skills are applicable when you make the Charisma check, depending on the interaction that precedes the roll.

entries.caption: Influence Skills
rows: Gently coaxing a Beast or a Monstrosity
Deceiving a creature that can understand you
Persuading a creature that can understand you

entries.name: Setting the DC
entries: The DM sets the check's DC. A good guideline is to set the DC at 15 or at the creature's Intelligence or Wisdom score, whichever of those three numbers is highest.

entries.name: Outcome
entries: If your check succeeds, the creature does as you requested or demanded, based on its understanding and driven by its alignment; it won't do anything that it finds repugnant. If your check fails, you must wait to make the same request again. The default wait time is 24 hours, which the DM may shorten or extend depending on the circumstances.

action.name: Magic
entries: When you take the Magic action, you magic something by casting a spell that has a casting time of an action or by using a feature or Magic Item that requires a Magic action to be activated.

If you cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 minute or longer, you must take the Magic action on each turn of that casting, and you must maintain {@status Concentration} while you do so. If your {@status Concentration} is broken, the spell fails, but you don't expend a spell slot.

action.name: Search
entries: When you take the Search action, you make a Wisdom check to discern something that isn't obvious. The Search table suggests which skills are applicable when you take this action, depending on what you're trying to detect.

action.name: Study
entries: When you take the Study action, you make an Intelligence check to study your memory, a book, a creature, a clue, an object, or another source of knowledge and call to mind an important piece of information about it.
The Areas of Knowledge table suggests which skills are applicable when you take this action, depending on the area of knowledge the Intelligence check is about.

entries.caption: Areas of Knowledge
rows: Spells, magic items, eldritch symbols, magical traditions, planes of existence, and certain creatures (Aberrations, Constructs, Elementals, Fey, and Monstrosities)
Historic events and people, ancient civilizations, wars, and certain creatures (Giants and Humanoids)
Terrain, flora, weather, and certain creatures (Beasts, Dragons, Oozes, and Plants)
Deities, religious hierarchies and rites, holy symbols, cults, and certain creatures (Celestials, Fiends, and Undead)

sense.name: Blindsight
entries: If you have Blindsight, you can see within a specific range without relying on physical sight. Within that range, you can effectively see anything that isn't behind Total Cover, even if you have the {@condition Blinded} condition or are in Darkness. Moreover, in that range, you can effectively see a creature that has the {@condition Invisible|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition.

sense.name: Tremorsense
entries: A creature with Tremorsense can pinpoint the location of creatures and moving objects within a specific range, provided that the creature with Tremorsense and anything it's detecting are both in contact with the same surface (such as the ground, a wall, or a ceiling) or the same liquid.
Tremorsense can't detect creatures or objects in the air, and Tremorsense doesn't count as a form of sight.

sense.name: Truesight
entries: A creature with Truesight has enhanced vision within a specified range. Within that range, the creature's vision pierces through the following:

items.name: Darkness
entries: The creature can see in normal and magical darkness.

items.name: Invisibility
entries: The creature can see creatures that have the {@condition Invisible|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition and objects that are obscured by magic.

items.name: Visual Illusions
entries: Visual illusions appear transparent to the creature, and the creature automatically succeeds on saving throws against them.

items.name: Transformations
entries: The creature discerns the true form of any creature or object it sees that has been transformed by magic.

items.name: Ethereal Plane
entries: The creature can see into the Ethereal Plane.

data.name: Unearthed Arcana 2023 Player's Handbook Playtest 7
entries: This playtest document is part of a series of {@i Unearthed Arcana} articles that present material designed for the 2024 version of the {@i Player's Handbook}. The material here uses the rules in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, except where noted.
After we conclude the public playtest for the {@i Player's Handbook}, {@i Unearthed Arcana} will explore material for the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} and {@i Monster Manual}.

entries.name: Learn More on YouTube
entries: To learn more about the design in this article, we invite you to view the videos about it on YouTube ({@link www.youtube.com/DNDWizards}).

entries.name: What's Inside
entries: Here are the new and revised elements in this article:

items.name: Classes
entries: Five classes are here: {@class Barbarian|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Fighter|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Sorcerer|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Warlock|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, and {@class Wizard|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}. Each of those classes includes multiple subclasses, two of which are entirely new: the {@class Barbarian|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Path of the World Tree|World Tree|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} in the Barbarian and the {@class Fighter|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Brawler|Brawler|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} in the Fighter.

items.name: Spells
entries: Revised spells are included.

items.name: Weapons
entries: Weapon revisions are included.

items: The following sections were introduced in a previous article and are provided here for reference:

items.name: Feats
entries: This includes a revised version of {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}.

items.name: Rules Glossary
entries: The rules glossary includes the few rules that have revised definitions in the playtest. In this document, any underlined term in the body text appears in the glossary.

entries.name: This Is Playtest Material
entries: This article is presented for playtesting and feedback. The options here are experimental and in draft form. They aren't officially part of the game. Your feedback will help determine whether we adopt it as official.

entries.name: How to Playtest This UA
entries: We invite you to try out this material in play. When you do so, you're welcome to combine this article with the other articles in this series, starting with "{@loader Character Origins.|collection/Unearthed Arcana 2022 - Character Origins.json|prerelease}"

If you do combine this article with any previous one, use only the rules glossary found here. In this {@i Unearthed Arcana} series, the rules glossary of each article supersedes the glossary of any previous article.

To play with this material, you may either incorporate it into your campaign or run one or more special playtest sessions. For such a session, you may create an adventure of your own or use a short adventure from a source like {@adventure Keys from the Golden Vault|KftGV}, {@adventure Journeys through the Radiant Citadel|JttRC}, or {@adventure Candlekeep Mysteries|CM}.

entries.name: Power Level
entries: The character options you read here might be more or less powerful than options in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}. If a design survives playtesting, we adjust its power to the desirable level before publication. This means an option could be more or less powerful in its final form.

entries.name: Feedback
entries: The best way for you to give us feedback on this material is in the survey we'll release on D&D Beyond. If we make this material official, it will be refined based on your feedback, and then it will appear in a D&D book.
Providing feedback on this document is one way you can help shape the next generation of D&D!

data.name: Classes
entries: {@note For full details of all classes including tables, multiclassing, equipment, core stats and fluff, please see {@filter the classes page|classes|source=XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}.}

entries.name: Design Note: Barbarian Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this class since its last playtest version:

items.name: Danger Sense
entries: returns to level 2. It now works even if you have the Blinded or Deafened condition.

items.name: Reckless Attack
entries: now grants Advantage to your Strength-based attack rolls until the start of your next turn, which means an Opportunity Attack can benefit, as can subclass features like Retaliation.

items.name: Primal Knowledge
entries: has moved to level 3 from 2, matching the level of Primal Knowledge in {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE}.

items.name: Instinctive Pounce
entries: has been imported from {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE}.

items.name: Brutal Critical
entries: returns to level 9, and now it deals {@damage 1d12} extra damage on a crit. This damage increases at higher levels.

items.name: Relentless Rage
entries: returns to level 11.

items.name: Persistent Rage
entries: returns to level 15, and the {@condition Unconscious|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition, not {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, shuts off your Rage. In addition, the feature incorporates the function of Rage Resurgence (regain a Rage on Initiative).

items.name: Indomitable Might
entries: returns to level 18, and it now applies to Strength saving throws and Strength checks.

items.name: Primal Champion
entries: returns to level 20 and once again increases the scores by 4.

entries.name: Barbarian Subclasses
entries: A Barbarian subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain levels, as specified in the subclass. This section presents the following subclasses: {@class Barbarian|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Path of the Berserker|Berserker|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Barbarian|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Path of the Wild Heart|Wild Heart|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Barbarian|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Path of the World Tree|World Tree|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, and {@class Barbarian|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Path of the Zealot|Zealot|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}.

entries.name: Design Note: Path of the Berserker Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since its last playtest version:

items.name: Intimidating Presence
entries: is now a Bonus Action rather than an action.

entries.name: Design Note: Path of the Wild Heart Updates
entries: Here are the main updates to the Path of the Wild Heart, formerly called the Path of the Totem Warrior, since the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}:

items.name: Animal Speaker,
entries: formerly called Spirit Seeker, now has its spellcasting ability specified.

items.name: Rage of the Wilds,
entries: formerly called Totem Spirit, contains revisions to each option. {@b Bear} no longer grants Resistance to all but one damage type. The former design was too powerful. It now allows you to gain Resistance to two damage types of your choice. {@b Eagle} lets you take both the Dash and the Disengage action when you activate your Rage and as a Bonus Action. The range of {@b Wolf} increases to 10 feet.

items.name: Aspect of the Wilds,
entries: formerly called Aspect of the Beast, contains revisions to each option. {@b Elephant} (formerly Bear) now grants proficiency in the Athletics or Insight skill, granting {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} if you already have proficiency. {@b Owl} (formerly Eagle) now grants proficiency in the Investigation or Perception skill, granting {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} if you already have proficiency. {@b Spider} (formerly Wolf) now grants proficiency in the Stealth or Survival skill, granting {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} if you already have proficiency.

items.name: Nature Speaker,
entries: formerly called Spirit Walker, now has its spellcasting ability specified.

items.name: Power of the Wilds,
entries: formerly called Totemic Attunement, contains revisions to each option. {@b Lion} (formerly Bear) is no longer stopped by immunity to the Frightened condition. {@b Falcon} (formerly Eagle) now allows a persistent {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} while your Rage is active, provided you aren't wearing any armor. {@b Ram} (formerly Wolf) no longer uses your Bonus Action but requires a saving throw.

entries.name: Design Note: Voluntarily Failing s Save
entries: The 2024 {@i Player's Handbook} will clarify that any creature can voluntarily fail any saving throw.

entries.name: Design Note: Path of the Zealot Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since its appearance in {@book Xanathar's Guide to Everything|XGE}:

items.name: Divine Fury
entries: now allows you to determine the damage type each time you deal the damage.

items.name: Warrior of the Gods
entries: now includes the ability to regain additional HP when healed by a spell or magic item.

items.name: Zealous Presence
entries: now allows you to use it multiple times between {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Long Rests} by expending uses of your Rage.

items.name: Rage Beyond Death
entries: now turns you into a warrior spirit after you successfully use your Relentless Rage.

entries.name: Design Note: Fighter Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this class since its last playtest version:

items.name: Fighting Style
entries: now lets you replace the feat you chose whenever you gain a Fighter level. This is inspired by Martial Versatility in {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE}.

items.name: Second Wind
entries: now also restores one expended use on a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}.

items.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: now maxes out at 6 Mastery options instead of 5.

items.name: Action Surge
entries: now allows any action, except the {@action Magic|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} action, and it once again improves at level 17.

items.name: Tactical Mind
entries: is a new level 2 feature, which allows the Fighter to excel in or out of combat.

items.name: Fighter Subclass
entries: and {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} return to their 2014 levels.

items.name: Tactical Shift
entries: is a new level 5 feature that lets you move without provoking Opportunity Attacks when you activate your Second Wind.

items.name: Master of Armaments
entries: replaces {@b Weapon Expert} and {@b Weapon Adept} at level 9. This new feature lets you change the Mastery properties of all your Mastery weapons.

items.name: Indomitable
entries: once again confers more uses at higher levels.

items.name: Studied Attacks
entries: is a new level 13 feature that increases the likelihood you'll hit after you miss.

items.name: Unconquerable
entries: has been cut in favor of Indomitable improving at higher levels.

items.name: Three Extra Attacks
entries: returns to level 20.

entries.name: Fighter Subclasses
entries: A Fighter subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain levels, as specified in the subclass. This section presents the following subclasses: {@class Fighter|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Battle Master|Battle Master|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Fighter|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Brawler|Brawler|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Fighter|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Champion|Champion|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, and {@class Fighter|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Eldritch Knight|Eldritch Knight|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}.

entries.name: Design Note: Battle Master Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}:

items.name: Student of War
entries: now also gives you proficiency in a skill.

items.name: Know Your Enemy
entries: now allows you to know a creature's damage resistances, immunities, and vulnerabilities as a Bonus Action.

items.name: Relentless
entries: now allows you to use a Maneuver once per turn without expending a Superiority Die, but that free Maneuver uses a {@dice d8}.

entries.name: Maneuvers Options
entries: The Maneuvers are presented here in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Design Note: Maneuver Updates
entries: Here are the main updates to the Maneuvers:

items.name: Ambush
entries: from {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE} is included.

items.name: Bait and Switch
entries: from {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE} is included.

items.name: Commander's Strike
entries: no longer uses your Bonus Action.

items.name: Commanding Presence
entries: from {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE} is included.

items.name: Disarming Attack, Distracting Strike, Goading Attack, Maneuvering Attack, Menacing Attack,
entries: and {@b Precision Attack} now work with any type of attack roll.

items.name: Evasive Footwork
entries: now lasts until the end of your turn, not when you stop moving.

items.name: Lunging Attack
entries: now lets you take the Dash action as a Bonus Action and adds the Superiority Die if you hit a creature after moving at least 10 feet in a straight line.

items.name: Parry
entries: now allows you to add your Strength or Dexterity modifier to the damage reduction.

items.name: Precision Attack
entries: now triggers from missing an attack roll, not before you know if the attack hit or not.

items.name: Rally
entries: now uses your choice of Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma when determining the amount of Temporary Hit Points gained.

items.name: Tactical Assessment
entries: from {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE} is included.

entries.name: Design Note: Magic Items for Unarmed Strikes and Improvised Weapons
entries: The 2024 Dungeon Master's Guide will include magic items that enhance {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Unarmed Strikes} and Improvised Weapons. These items will support the Monk, Brawler Fighter, and College of Dance Bard, along with other characters who rely on {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Unarmed Strikes} or Improvised Weapons.

entries.name: Design Note: Champion Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since its last playtest version:

items.name: Remarkable Athlete
entries: replaces Adaptable Victor and moves to level 3. It now grants Advantage on Initiative rolls and Strength (Athletics) checks, in addition to increasing long-jump distance.

items.name: Heroic Warrior
entries: now gives you {@variantrule Heroic Advantage|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} at the start of each of your turns in combat.

entries.name: Design Note: Eldritch Knight Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}:

items.name: Spellcasting
entries: contains no school-of-magic restrictions after level 3 in the subclass. Moreover, the Fighter can now change one cantrip when gaining a level, and the Fighter can use an Arcane Focus.

items.name: War Magic
entries: now allows you to replace one of your attacks with casting a cantrip, allowing the Eldritch Knight to weave magic into their attacks.

items.name: Improved War Magic
entries: now allows you to replace two of your attacks with casting a level 1 or 2 spell, allowing the Eldritch Knight to further weave magic into their attacks.

entries.name: Design Note: Sorcerer Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this class since its last playtest version:

items.name: Innate Sorcery
entries: empowers your spells' attack rolls and save DCs for a limited time.

items.name: Spellcasting
entries: returns to using the Sorcerer spell list rather than the Arcane spell list. The Sorcerer list now includes {@spell Sorcerous Burst|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} and {@spell Arcane Eruption|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, both of which appear in this document.

items.name: Font of Magic
entries: no longer requires a Bonus Action to convert spell slots into Sorcery Points.

items.name: Metamagic
entries: gives you two options at level 2 and two more at levels 10 and 17 each, and you can now change one of your options whenever you gain a Sorcerer level.

items.name: Sorcerer Subclass
entries: returns to the 2014 level progression for Sorcerer subclasses, with the exception of the level 1 feature being at level 3.

items.name: Sorcerous Vitality
entries: is gone.

items.name: Sorcerous Restoration
entries: has moved from level 15 to 5. If you have no Sorcery Points when you roll Initiative, this feature restores a certain number.

items.name: Sorcery Incarnate
entries: has moved from level 9 to 7 and has been redesigned to enhance Innate Sorcery.

items.name: Arcane Apotheosis
entries: has moved to level 20 and has been redesigned to enhance Innate Sorcery.

entries.name: Metamagic Options
entries: The following options are available to your Metamagic features. The options are presented in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Design Note: Metamagic Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in the Metamagic options since their last playtest version.

items.name: Distant Spell
entries: returns to doubling range.

items.name: Seeking Spell
entries: now costs 1 point rather than 2.

items.name: Subtle Spell
entries: now clarifies that it doesn't remove Material components that have a cost specified in the affected spell.

items.name: Twinned Spell
entries: has some of its previous multitargeting functionality but now within appropriate limits.

entries.name: Sorcerer Subclasses
entries: A Sorcerer subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Sorcerer levels, as specified in the subclass. This section presents the following subclasses: {@class Sorcerer|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Draconic Sorcery|Draconic|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} and {@class Sorcerer|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Wild Magic Sorcery|Wild Magic|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}. See {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE} for {@class Sorcerer|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Aberrant Sorcery|Aberrant|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} (aka {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Aberrant Mind|Aberrant Mind|TCE}) and {@class Sorcerer|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Clockwork Sorcery|Clockwork|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} (aka {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Clockwork Soul|Clockwork Soul|TCE}).

entries.name: Design Note: Draconic Sorcery Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since its last playtest appearance:

items.name: Dragon Speech
entries: now gives you the Draconic language, and while creatures of the Dragon type understand your speech, you don't necessarily understand them.

items.name: Dragon Wings
entries: once again allows you to sprout wings without relying on a spell.

items.name: Draconic Presence
entries: replaces Draconic Exhalation. The feature is now a Bonus Action, and it doesn't require Concentration.

entries.name: Design Note: Wild Magic Sorcery Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}:

items.name: Wild Magic Surge
entries: no longer requires DM permission.

items.name: Tides of Chaos
entries: is now guaranteed to give you a roll on the Wild Magic Surge table.

items.name: Bend Luck
entries: now costs 1 Sorcery Point instead of 2.

items.name: Wild Bombardment
entries: (formerly Spell Bombardment) now allows you to use a Wild Magic Surge effect that casts a spell or that replenishes your expended Sorcery Points.

entries.name: Aberrant & Clockwork Sorcery
entries: {@note See {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE} for {@class Sorcerer|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Aberrant Sorcery|Aberrant|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} (aka {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Aberrant Mind|Aberrant Mind|TCE}) and {@class Sorcerer|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Clockwork Sorcery|Clockwork|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} (aka {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Clockwork Soul|Clockwork Soul|TCE}).}

entries.name: Design Note: Warlock Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this class since its last playtest version:

items: The class's {@b Armor Training} entry returns to including only Light Armor.

items.name: Pact Magic
entries: returns.

items.name: Eldritch Invocations
entries: moves to level 1, and at level 20, you have 10 invocations rather than 8. Many of the invocations are revised, as detailed in their section.

items.name: Pact Boon
entries: is integrated into the Eldritch Invocations feature. Over time, you're now able to choose more than one of the former Pact Boon options.

items.name: Magical Cunning
entries: is a new level 2 feature that allows a Warlock to quickly regain a certain number of spell slots.

items.name: Contact Patron
entries: moves to level 9.

items.name: Mystic Arcanum
entries: returns to being a core feature, and it now allows you to replace one of its spells whenever you gain a level in this class.

items.name: Hex Master
entries: is gone.

items.name: Eldritch Master
entries: returns to level 20.

entries.name: Eldritch Invocation Options
entries: The following options are available to your Eldritch Invocations feature. The options are presented in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Design Note: Eldritch Invocation Updates
entries: Here's a summary of the main changes to the invocation options since they appeared in "{@loader Player's Handbook Playtest 5|collection/Unearthed Arcana 2023 - Player's Handbook Playtest 5.json|prerelease}":

items.name: Agonizing Blast
entries: now lets you choose which Warlock cantrip benefits from the invocation.

items.name: Ascendent Step
entries: now requires level 5+ rather than level 9+.

items.name: Beast Speech
entries: is gone, since {@spell Speak with Animals} is now on the Warlock spell list and can be cast as a Ritual.

items.name: Devil's Sight
entries: now works in Dim Light as well as in Darkness.

items.name: Eldritch Mind
entries: has been imported from {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE}.

items.name: Eldritch Sight
entries: is gone, since {@spell Detect Magic} is now on the Warlock spell list and can be cast as a ritual.

items.name: Eldritch Smite
entries: has been imported from {@book Xanathar's Guide to Everything|XGE}.

items.name: Eldritch Spear
entries: now lets you choose which Warlock cantrip benefits from the invocation.

items.name: Eyes of the Rune Keeper
entries: has been removed, since {@spell Comprehend Languages} is on the Warlock spell list and can be cast as a ritual.

items.name: Favor of the Chain Master
entries: has been cut in favor of importing Investment of the Chain Master from {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE}.

items.name: Fiendish Vigor
entries: no longer requires you to roll a die when casting {@spell False Life}; you instead gain the maximum number of Temporary Hit Points.

items.name: Gaze of Two Minds
entries: now works on any willing creature, not just Humanoids, and to cast spells from the other creature's space, you must be within 60 feet of each other.

items.name: Gift of the Depths
entries: has been imported from {@book Xanathar's Guide to Everything|XGE}.

items.name: Eldritch Mind
entries: from {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE} replaces Hexer.

items.name: Investment of the Chain Master
entries: has been imported from {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE}.

items.name: Lessons of the First Ones
entries: can now be taken more than once.

items.name: Lifedrinker
entries: now lets you choose to deal Necrotic, Psychic, or Radiant damage, and its healing is connected to your Hit Dice.

items.name: Master of Myriad Forms
entries: now requires level 5+ rather than level 15+.

items.name: One with Shadows
entries: now lets you cast {@spell Invisibility} without a spell slot while you're in Dim Light or Darkness.

items.name: Otherworldly Leap
entries: now requires level 2+ rather than level 9+.

items.name: Pact of the Blade, Pact of the Chain,
entries: and {@b Pact of the Tome} are now invocations. Pact of the Chain includes additional familiar options, and Pact of the Tome now gives you a level 1 spell slot.

items.name: Thirsting Blade
entries: returns, and it now improves at level 11.

items.name: Visions of Distant Realms
entries: now requires level 9+ rather than level 15+.

items.name: Whispers of the Grave
entries: now requires level 7+ rather than level 9+.

entries.name: Warlock Subclasses
entries: A Warlock subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Warlock levels, as specified in the subclass. This section presents the following subclasses: {@class Warlock|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Archfey Patron|Archfey|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Warlock|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Celestial Patron|Celestial|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Warlock|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Fiend Patron|Fiend|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, and {@class Warlock|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Great Old One Patron|Great Old One|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}.

entries.name: Design Note: Archfey Patron Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}:

items.name: Patron Spells
entries: (formerly called Expanded Spell List) now lets you have its spells always prepared, and it includes {@spell Misty Step}.

items.name: Steps of the Fey
entries: (formerly Fey Presence) now gives you the {@spell Misty Step} spell and ways to modify it.

items.name: Misty Escape
entries: now modifies your {@spell Misty Step} spell and expands your choices from Steps of the Fey.

items.name: Beguiling Defenses
entries: now reacts to you taking damage.

items.name: Bewitching Magic
entries: (formerly Dark Delirium) allows you to cast {@spell Misty Step} whenever you cast an Enchantment or Illusion spell using a spell slot.

entries.name: Design Note: Celestial Patron Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since its appearance in {@book Xanathar's Guide to Everything|XGE}:

items.name: Patron Spells
entries: (formerly called Expanded Spell List and Bonus Cantrips) now lets you have its spells always prepared.

items.name: Celestial Resilience
entries: now works with Magical Cunning.

entries.name: Design Note: Fiend Patron Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since its last playtest version:

items.name: Patron Spells
entries: is updated to reflect the return of Pact Magic. The list of spells is revised, and the free casting is gone in favor of the spell-slot recovery in Magical Cunning.

items.name: Dark One's Blessing
entries: now works when someone else reduces an enemy within 10 feet of you to 0 Hit Points.

items.name: Dark One's Own Luck
entries: can be used only once per roll.

items.name: Hurl Through Hell
entries: requires a Charisma saving throw before affecting the target. The damage is now {@damage 8d10}, and the target has the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition while hurtling through the Lower Planes.

entries.name: Design Note: Great Old One Patron Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}:

items.name: Patron Spells
entries: (formerly called Expanded Spell List) now lets you have its spells always prepared, and some of the spells have changed.

items.name: Awakened Mind
entries: now lets you create a two-way telepathic connection with another creature.

items.name: Psychic Spells
entries: is a new level 3 feature.

items.name: Clairvoyant Combatant
entries: (formerly Entropic Ward) uses your telepathic bond to impose Disadvantage on attack rolls against you and grant you Advantage on attack rolls against the creature for the duration of the telepathic bond.

items.name: Eldritch Hex
entries: is a new level 10 feature.

items.name: Create Thrall
entries: now gives you the {@spell Summon Aberration|TCE} spell with additional properties.

entries.name: Design Note: Wizard Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this class since its last playtest version:

items.name: Arcane Recovery
entries: returns to level 1.

items.name: Spellcasting
entries: now allows you to change a cantrip whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, incorporating the functionality of the Cantrip Formulas feature in {@book Tasha's Cauldron of Everything|TCE}. This feature also returns to using the Wizard spell list, and the total number of spells prepared has increased since the last playtest.

items.name: Wizard's Spellbook
entries: is absorbed into the Spellcasting feature.

items.name: Scholar
entries: replaces Academic at level 2, and it offers {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} in one skill chosen from a list.

items.name: Memorize Spell
entries: is now a feature rather than a spell. It allows you to prepare a spell that you didn't already have prepared.

items.name: Modify Spell
entries: and Create Spell are gone.

items.name: Spell Mastery
entries: returns to level 18. In addition, the chosen spells must have a casting time of an action, you always have them prepared, and you can change one of them whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}. Allowing at-will casting of non-action spells, such as {@spell Shield}, was too powerful.

items.name: Signature Spells
entries: returns to level 20.

entries.name: Wizard Subclasses
entries: A Wizard subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Wizard levels, as specified in the subclass. This section presents the following subclasses: {@class Wizard|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Abjurer|Abjurer|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Wizard|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Diviner|Diviner|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, {@class Wizard|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Evoker|Evoker|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, and {@class Wizard|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7|Illusionist|Illusionist|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}.

entries.name: Design Note: Abjurer Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}:

items.name: Abjuration Savant
entries: now adds one Abjuration spell to your spellbook whenever you gain access to a new level of spell slots in this class. This benefit replaces the rarely used discount.

items.name: Arcane Ward
entries: now requires you to spend a spell slot to create it, and it allows you to expend a spell slot without casting a spell to restore it.

items.name: Spell Breaker
entries: replaces Improved Abjuration.

entries.name: Design Note: Diviner Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}:

items.name: Divination Savant
entries: now adds one Divination spell to your spellbook whenever you gain access to a new level of spell slots in this class. This benefit replaces the rarely used discount.

items.name: The Third Eye
entries: is now a Bonus Action rather than an action, and it allows you to cast the {@spell See Invisibility} spell instead of having to choose between seeing the invisible or seeing into the Ethereal Plane. Finally, the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} condition no longer shuts this feature off.

entries.name: Design Note: Evoker Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since its last playtest version:

items.name: Evocation Savant
entries: now adds one Evocation spell to your spellbook whenever you gain access to a new level of spell slots in this class. This benefit replaces the rarely used discount.

items.name: Potent Cantrip
entries: moves to level 3. This change gives the Evoker a feature that can be enjoyed regularly.

items.name: Sculpt Spells
entries: moves to level 6. Few spells at lower levels benefited from it. At level 6, it can benefit many iconic spells.

entries.name: Design Note: Illusionist Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this subclass since the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}:

items.name: Illusion Savant
entries: now adds one Illusion spell to your spellbook whenever you gain access to a new level of spell slots in this class. This benefit replaces the rarely used discount.

items.name: Malleable Illusions
entries: is now a Bonus Action rather than an action.

items.name: Illusory Self
entries: can be reused by expending a spell slot of level 2 or higher.

items.name: Illusory Reality
entries: has been clarified, noting that it can't deal damage or give any conditions.

data.name: Spells
entries: This section presents new or revised spells for you to playtest.

entries.name: Class Tags
entries: A spell's description contains one or more tags indicating the class spell lists that contain the spell. For example, if a spell has the "Wizard" tag, the spell is on the Wizard spell list.

entries.name: Spell Descriptions
entries: The following spells are presented in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Design Note: Spell Updates
entries: Here are the main updates in this section since its last playtest version:

items: The {@b Arcane}, {@b Divine}, and {@b Primal} lists are gone. All spellcasting classes return to using their own lists.

items.name: Arcane Eruption
entries: now requires a Dexterity save rather than a Constitution save.

items.name: Counterspell
entries: now requires the target to make a saving throw, instead of requiring the caster to make an ability check. The spell's previous design failed to account for the capabilities of the target, which is rectified by the new design. The new design also specifies that the countered spell must be cast with spell components, and if the countered spell used a spell slot, that slot isn't expended.

items.name: Eldritch Blast
entries: and {@b Hex} revert to their 2014 versions.

items.name: Jump
entries: is now a Bonus Action, its target must be willing, its benefit no longer relies on your Strength or Speed, and it can be improved at higher levels.

items.name: Sorcerous Burst
entries: now uses a {@damage d8} for damage rather than a {@damage d6}.

data.name: Feats
entries: This section offers a collection of character feats, which are special features not tied to a single character class.

entries.name: Parts of a Feat
entries: The description of a feat contains the following parts, which are presented after the feat's name:

items.name: Prerequisite
entries: You must meet any prerequisite specified in a feat to take that feat unless a special feature allows you to take the feat without the prerequisite. If a prerequisite is a level, your character level must meet or exceed that level. If a prerequisite is a class, you must have at least one level in that class to qualify for the feat.

items.name: Benefit
entries: The benefit of the feat is then detailed. If you have a feat, you gain its benefit.

items.name: Repeatable
entries: A feat can be taken only once unless it states otherwise.

entries.name: Feat Descriptions
entries: Here are descriptions of some feats that are available to characters using this playtest article. Playtest characters can also select feats from previous installments of the 2022 {@i Unearthed Arcana} series.
If a feat appears in this article and also in one of those earlier articles, use the version of the feat in this article.
The following feats are presented in alphabetical order.

data.name: Weapons
entries: This section contains playtest versions of weapons in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}. Here you'll find weapon tables, revised weapon properties, and a new type of property: Mastery properties.

entries.name: Design Note: Weapon Updates
entries: Here are the main changes to this section since its last playtest version:

items: The {@b Heavy} property is redesigned. Rather than being based on size, it's based on your Strength or Dexterity score.
The {@b Push} property now works on any creature that is Large or smaller, and it requires you to push the target straight away from yourself.
The {@b Sap} property now works with weapons that have the Versatile property or no property.
The {@b Quarterstaff} now has the Topple property.
The {@b Spear} now has the Sap property.
The {@b Longsword} now has the Sap property.
The {@b Warhammer} now has the Push property.
The {@b War Pick} now has the Sap property.

entries.name: Weapon Properties
entries: Here are properties whose definitions have changed for this playtest.

entries.name: Heavy
entries: A Heavy weapon is unwieldy compared to other weapons. You have Disadvantage on your attack rolls with a Heavy weapon if it's a melee weapon and your Strength score isn't at least 13 and if it's a ranged weapon and your Dexterity score isn't at least 13.

entries.name: Light
entries: When you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} action on your turn and attack with a Light weapon, you can make one extra attack as a Bonus Action later on the same turn. That extra attack must be made with a different Light weapon, and you don't add your ability modifier to the extra attack's damage, unless that modifier is negative.

For example, if you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7} action on your turn and have a Shortsword in one hand and a Dagger in the other—each of which has the Light property—you can make one attack with each weapon, using your action and a Bonus Action, but you don't add your Strength or Dexterity modifier to the damage roll of the Bonus Action, unless that modifier is negative.

entries.name: Thrown
entries: If a weapon has the Thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack, and you can draw that weapon as part of the attack.

If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a Handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a Dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the Dagger has the Finesse property.

entries.name: Mastery Properties
entries: Each weapon now has a Mastery property, as shown in the weapon tables above. That property is usable only by a character who has a feature, such as Weapon Mastery, that unlocks the property for the character.
Here are descriptions of each Mastery property. The properties are provided in alphabetical order.
If a game feature lets you replace a weapon's Mastery property with another one, that weapon must meet any prerequisite specified for the new property.

data.name: Adventuring Gear
entries: Here are descriptions of miscellaneous items whose rules have changed for this playtest.

data.name: Rules Glossary
entries: This glossary includes game terms that have new meaning in this playtest document, as well as terms, such as {@variantrule creature type|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP7}, that aren't defined in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}. The terms are organized alphabetically.

If a term doesn't appear here, use its definition in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, and when playtesting this document, don't use the rules glossary of any other {@i Unearthed Arcana} article.

entries.name: Design Note: Rules Glossary Update
entries: The section on death saving throws has been removed.
